Index.title: We’re committed to your safety, comfort, and freedom to explore.
Index.subtitle: Create a custom trip & get a price quote within 24 hours.

About.title: ABOUT US
About.text: We started our company in 2024. Though we’re a young travel company, our team brings years of experience and a genuine love for what we do. Each of us is an expert in our field, and together, we create travel experiences that are unique, smooth, and full of great memories. Whether it’s our passionate guides or our careful planners, every detail matters to us. We’re here to offer a new kind of adventure—where fresh ideas meet deep expertise. Join us and discover travel made with heart and skill. Welcome to a journey like no other!
About.subtitle: SAIBAI TOUR
About.cars_desc: Mongolia’s roads are mostly unpaved and can be challenging due to natural conditions. That’s why we provide reliable, durable vehicles to ensure your comfort and safety. Our fleet includes everything from rugged Russian military vans to modern, comfortable 4x4s and large buses, suitable for all types of travel.

mission_desc.title: To be the best at what we do—crafting meaningful journeys that help others truly experience the very best of Mongolia.
To connect travelers with authentic local cultures while supporting and empowering the communities we visit.
To promote sustainable tourism by minimizing environmental impact and preserving Mongolia’s natural and cultural heritage.
To provide personalized, flexible travel experiences that exceed our clients’ expectations in quality, comfort, adventure and safety.
To build lasting relationships with our clients through exceptional service, professionalism, and genuine care before, during, and after every trip.

About.team_desc: As a service-oriented company, we have over thirty five full and part-time personnel working across the country during the main travel season. All team members are well-trained, highly experienced, and deeply knowledgeable about local areas and the needs of both hosts and guests. Our managers, who specialize in markets including English, Korean, Chinese, Russian, and Japanese, communicate effectively with partners to quickly design and tailor unique itineraries that meet clients’ wishes, all while offering the best and most competitive prices. Our guides and local tour leaders are essential to ensuring safe and enjoyable adventures, and they are fluent in English, Korean, Russian, Japanese, and Chinese.
About.staff_desc: Saibai Tour is a specialist tour operator offering the best holidays in Mongolia. Our team includes four full-time office staff, supported by a wide network of partners across the country—from nomadic communities and multilingual guides to tourist camps, transportation providers, hotels, restaurants, and entertainment venues. With our personal approach and attention to detail, we aim to make your trip truly unforgettable. Our well-trained and experienced staff know the local areas deeply and understand the needs of both hosts and guests. We’re always available to assist you with any questions or requests.

Contacts.title: CONTACTS
Contacts.header: Get in Touch with Eternal Sky Tour
Contacts.text: Our friendly and experienced team is always here to answer any questions about our travel products and services. Just fill out the form below, and we’ll get back to you quickly—often in no time at all!
Contacts.third: and we will get back to you.
Contacts.name: Name
Contacts.agree: I agree to the terms and conditions

Events.title: EVENTS

camel-festival.title: Camel festival
camel-festival.text: This thrilling festival was first initiated in 1997 by the locals of Umnugovi Province (South Gobi) to celebrate Mongolian camels and protect the species and pass the rich Mongolian camel breeding heritage to the next generation. Nomads from afar and near wear their best traditional costumes and ride their best camels to attend the Festival.

itinerary.description: Arrival in Ulaanbaatar / City tour
Early in the morning drive to the South Gobi
CAMEL FESTIVAL day
CAMEL FESTIVAL day
Travel back to Ulaanbaatar. Shopping and free time. Dinner / Mongolian food.

eagle-festival.title: Eagle festival
eagle-festival.text: Join the Kazakh Eagle Hunters on a hunt during the cold winter months. The Kazakhs use eagles to hunt for foxes and hares that are easy to see against the snow. Freezing temperatures and long days on Mongolian horses discourage most people from attempting this adventure. For those who do, seeing an eagle released from a man's forearm swoop down and kill a fox a mile away is a truly unforgettable experience.

itinerary.description: Arrival in Ulaanbaatar

Take a flight to Ulgii (Bayan-Ulgii Province) and transfer to the Festival place, located only 45 kms from Ulgii airport. Meet the Kazakh eagle-hunters. The rodeo of eagle-hunting. A fantastic opportunity for photographers and adventurers alike to see these magnificent birds up close. There are approx. 400 eagle-hunters in Bayan-Ulgii aimag. The eagle-hunters from around regions gather to test their finely trained birds in singular contests of speed and agility in these few days.
Attend the Eagle Festival
Fly back to Ulaanbaatar

ice-festival.title: Ice festival
ice-festival.text: Nomadic reindeer herders and shamans show off their cultural performances, such as art, music and shaman rituals. This Ice Festival has been developing year by year. International visitors come to the Festival to capture scenic images and experience winter Mongolia and nomadic culture. It is worth to visit here.

itinerary.description: Arrival in Ulaanbaatar
Drive to Erdenet City and stay in hotel
After breakfast drive to Khuvsgul Lake
Enjoy the first day of Ice Festival
Enjoy the second day of Ice Festival
Back to Ulaanbaatar

naadam-festival.title: Naadam festival
naadam-festival.text: The core of the festival – three manly sports – the wrestling, horse-racing and archery embrace many elements of art, such as singing, dancing and performing. Nomadic Mongolians have known when to throw the parties. Naadam Festival is held in the most enjoyable month of the most pleasant season in the country. Therefore, everyone takes the opportunity and enjoys the Festival in diverse schedule such as travelling to the countryside, camping out and gathering in their closest herds.

itinerary.description: Arrival in Ulaanbaatar City tour
The Opening Ceremony of the Naadam Festival Day
Explore the Terelj National Park & the Chinggis Khaan Statue Complex. Drive back to Ulaanbaatar

tsagaan-sar.title: Tsagaan Sar
tsagaan-sar.text: Winter in Mongolia is a remarkable experience for those willing to take themselves outside of their comfort zone. Pack your thermals and come to Mongolia this winter and do something a little out of the ordinary. Come and enjoy being part of a minority who visit Mongolia in the winter and actually interact with the local people and enjoy slowing-down and seeing and experiencing Mongolia like few other people get to do.

itinerary.description: Arrival in Ulaanbaatar (we will pick you up from the airport)
Drive to Chinggis Khaan Statue, go to a local family, celebrate Lunar New Year eve (homestay)
Attending first day of Lunar New Year, try Mongolian cuisine
Drive to Terelj National Park
Back to Ulaanbaatar and go to the airport

event-container.title: TSAGAAN SAR
event-container.description: "Tsagaan Sar" /White Month/ takes place in the beginning of spring and is the biggest annual celebration in Mongolia. We recommend you to experience this festival and discover your memorable trip.

event-container.title: ICE FESTIVAL
event-container.description: Local communities gather on the lake for the winter Ice Festival. Several winter and cultural activities are held each year such as ice skating, horse sleighing race, ice sumo and traditional winter games and competitions.

event-container.title: EAGLE FESTIVAL
event-container.description: Every year, the eagle hunters of the Altai Mountains in western Mongolia take part in a competition to show which of the 90 to 100 competing eagles is the best in speed, agility, beauty and hunting skills.

event-container.title: CAMEL FESTIVAL
event-container.description: Travel south to the Gobi Desert to attend the renowned "Thousand Camel Festival". It is already one of the most famous winter festivals in the world, organized by a local non-governmental organization working to protect and preserve the Bactrian camel population, which has been steadily declining over the past twelve years.

event-container.title: NAADAM FESTIVAL
event-container.description: Naadam Festival is the only one of its kind; it is a sophisticated and eloquent expression of nomadic culture. It is the honored celebration of a national independence, and it is an outstanding combination of arts and sports.

Events.headerDescription: Experience the vibrant culture and traditions of Mongolia through our carefully curated festival tours. From the colorful celebrations of Tsagaan Sar to the thrilling competitions of Naadam, join us for unforgettable cultural experiences that showcase the heart and soul of Mongolian heritage.

Information.title: ABOUT MONGOLIA
Information.subtitle: BASIC INFORMATION
Information.text: Mongolia remains one of the world’s last truly untouched travel frontiers—and one of the safest destinations you can explore. It is a vast land of striking contrasts, where endless steppes stretch beneath cobalt-blue skies, framed by forests, deserts, crystal-clear lakes, and winding rivers. Here, traditional nomadic hospitality is a way of life, and the warmth of the people is as enduring as the wide-open landscapes they call home. With few permanent structures and almost no fences, the countryside feels like one vast National Park, free and open to all. Mongolia offers unmatched opportunities for outdoor adventure—whether you're trekking on horseback, camping under the stars, or simply taking in the pristine natural beauty that surrounds you. Beyond its landscapes, Mongolia is rich in history, most famously as the heart of the Mongol Empire led by Genghis Khan, whose legacy continues to shape the national identity. In every direction, Mongolia invites discovery. It is a land of nomads, adventure, and horses under an ever-stretching blue sky—a place where time slows down, and ancient traditions live on.
Information.cuisine_desc: Savor the rich and hearty flavors of Mongolian cuisine, deeply connected to the land and traditions of the nomadic lifestyle. From tender meat dishes and creamy dairy treats to the subtle use of wild herbs and berries, Mongolian food offers a natural and satisfying taste experience. Each meal reflects the way of life shaped by the vast steppes and changing seasons. Discover the simplicity and depth of flavors that have been passed down for generations. Every bite tells a story—of family, tradition, and the untouched beauty of Mongolia.
Information.culture_desc: Discover the magic of Mongolia, a truly unique and welcoming destination. This vast, untouched land offers breathtaking open landscapes, from endless steppes and deserts to clear rivers and green forests, all beneath a wide blue sky. Nomadic herders warmly welcome visitors into their traditional way of life, where permanent homes are rare and the land feels like one great National Park. Rich in history, Mongolia is the birthplace of the legendary Genghis Khan and a land shaped by centuries of tradition. Ride horses, meet nomads, and explore wide open spaces unlike anywhere else on Earth. Mongolia is waiting to inspire and amaze you.
Information.kashmere_desc: Experience the pinnacle of luxury with Mongolia’s finest cashmere, celebrated worldwide for its exceptional softness and quality. Dive into the realm of premium leather goods, where skilled Mongolian artisans craft products that combine durability with timeless style. From silky-soft leather accessories to expertly made pieces, Mongolia’s craftsmanship shines through in every detail. Indulge in the unmatched comfort and elegance of cashmere and leather—true symbols of Mongolia’s dedication to quality and refinement. Discover the sophisticated touch that only authentic Mongolian cashmere and leather can offer.
Information.music: Music, Ballet, Musical, Plays in UB

music_list.title: Tumen Enkh National Song & Dance Ensemble

restaurante_list.title: Contemporary & classy: Rosewood, Choijin Lama Temple, Zoma Kitchen & Bar, Route 22

Burger places: Ruby room, The birch
Hot Pot: The Bull, Momo Hotpot
Artsy coffee & food: Exhibition Coffee Bar, Pastel

transport.title: Train ticket
transport.description: The Trans-Siberian Railway is the longest continuous rail line in the world and a must-experience journey for any adventurous traveler. Stretching 7,925 kilometers from Beijing to St. Petersburg, Russia, this legendary route connects Moscow, Ulaanbaatar, and Beijing. You can begin your adventure at any of these iconic cities and immerse yourself in three distinct and fascinating cultures along the way.

transport.title: Car rental
transport.description: Explore Mongolia with ease and freedom by renting a car through our travel agency, with or without a driver. Choose from a wide selection of vehicles—from sturdy 4x4s built for rugged off-road adventures to comfortable sedans perfect for city travel. Enjoy the flexibility to create your own itinerary and experience Mongolia’s stunning landscapes at your own pace.

transport.title: Flights
transport.description: Experience the skies of Mongolia with our efficient and convenient air travel services. Fly smoothly to your chosen destinations, whether it’s a quick domestic trip or a unique aerial adventure. We’ll help tailor your flights to perfectly fit your travel plans and needs.

insurance.title: Travel Insurance
insurance.text1: At Saibai Tour, we understand that unexpected situations can happen while traveling. Mongolia is one of the most sparsely populated countries in the world, with vast distances between towns and limited access to emergency services in remote areas.
insurance.text2: That’s why we highly recommend all travelers purchase comprehensive travel insurance that includes medical evacuation (medivac) and other relevant coverage for your trip.
insurance.text3: Having the right insurance gives you peace of mind and ensures you're protected in case of medical emergencies, trip interruptions, lost baggage, or delays.
insurance.text4: If you're unsure which insurance to choose, feel free to contact us — we’re happy to advise or recommend trusted travel insurance providers.
insurance.text5: Your safety and well-being are our top priority.

phone.pageDescription: Stay connected during your journey in Mongolia. Choose from the country's leading mobile providers to get reliable coverage and data services throughout your travels.

title.title: Mobicom
title.description: Mobicom is Mongolia's largest mobile operator with 95% network coverage and over 1.6 million users. They offer the widest coverage in the country, extending to remote areas. Mobicom provides both physical SIM cards and eSIM options for tourists, making it the most convenient choice for international travelers visiting Mongolia.
title.budget: Recommended Budget: $8-15 USD per month for data packages

title.title: Unitel
title.description: Unitel is Mongolia's second-largest mobile operator with 88% population coverage. They were the first to launch 5G services in Mongolia and offer comprehensive 4G LTE coverage. With extensive network infrastructure and high-speed data services, Unitel is perfect for travelers who need reliable connectivity throughout their journey.
title.budget: Recommended Budget: $10-20 USD per month for data packages

title.title: G-Mobile
title.description: G-Mobile is Mongolia's first 3G operator, focusing on affordable plans and rural connectivity. They offer extensive coverage in remote areas through CDMA technology and provide 4G LTE services with speeds up to 75 Mbps. Ideal for travelers seeking cost-effective mobile solutions with reliable coverage across Mongolia.

title.title: Skytel
title.description: Skytel provides comprehensive telecommunications services including mobile communications, IPTV, and broadband internet. With roaming coverage in over 240 countries and strong market presence, Skytel offers reliable connectivity and innovative services. Their fiber optic network ensures high-quality internet and streaming services.

title.title: Ondo
title.description: Ondo is Mongolia's newest mobile operator, focusing on advanced 5G technology and IoT networks. They offer innovative satellite services for areas without network coverage, including real-time tracking and monitoring services. Ondo is ideal for tech-savvy travelers and those visiting remote locations.

phone.text: Unitel, G-Mobile, Mobicom, Skytel, and Ondo are prominent mobile providers in Mongolia. Unitel boasts extensive coverage and high-speed data services. G-Mobile focuses on affordable plans and innovative offerings. Mobicom, a pioneer, offers diverse telecom solutions. Skytel, known for reliability, excels in communication services and cutting-edge technologies. Ondo provides modern mobile services and connectivity solutions. Together, they shape Mongolia's dynamic mobile landscape.
phone.recommendedText: We recommend this operator for travelers due to its broad coverage throughout Mongolia.

visa.title: HOW TO GET MONGOLIAN VISA?
visa.text1: Most visitors need a visa to enter Mongolia, but some countries are visa-exempt for short stays. You can apply for a visa at a Mongolian embassy before your trip. If there isn’t one in your country, you can get a 30-day visa on arrival at the airport or railway station for about $50. We’ll provide an official invitation letter to help with your visa application when you book with us.
visa.ul1: Belarus, Brazil, Canada, Kazakhstan, Macao, USA – no need a visa for a visit not exceeding three months
visa.ul2: German, Israel, Japan, Malaysia, Russia, Turkey - no need a visa for a visit not exceeding one month
visa.ul3: Philippines - no need a visa for a visit not exceeding three weeks
visa.ul4: Singapore, Hong Kong - no need a visa for a visit not exceeding two weeks
visa.ul5: People's Republic of China, Vietnam, Bulgaria, Thailand, Romania and Chile – who has diplomatic or official passport - no need a visa for a visit
visa.ul6: Indian travelers need a visa but don’t have to pay the visa fee.
visa.ul7: Hungary, Democratic People's Republic of Korea, Republic of Korea - who has diplomatic or official passport - no need a visa for a visit not exceeding three months
visa.ul8: India – needs Mongolian visa without visa fee
visa.ul9: Cuba – no need a visa for a visit not exceeding one month
visa.text2: Mongolian visas are issued by Mongolian Diplomatic Missions abroad or upon arrival at a special request. The Mongolian Embassies Abroad list
visa.subtitle2: THE FOLLOWING MATERIALS ARE REQUIRED TO OBTAIN MONGOLIAN VISA:
visa.materials3: APPLICATION FORM PDF (VISA APPLICATION FORM) (VISA APPLICATION FORM FOR TOURIST)
visa.materials4: EITHER AN INVITATION OF THE RECEIVING ENTITY (STATE, GOVERNMENT, NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATION, BUSINESS ENTITY) OR AN OFFICIAL REQUEST OF THE SENDING COUNTRY AND THE ORGANIZATION.
visa.materials5: Or, for tourists wishing to stay over 30 days up to 90 days, a letter of invitation from a travel agency of Mongolia. Please let us know if you need a letter of invitation.
visa.materials6: Or, if you are traveling on a personal invitation of a citizen of Mongolia, an invitation approved by the Office of Immigration, Naturalization and Foreign Citizens of Mongolia, and applicant's written statement concerning his/her financial credibility to cover his/her stay in Mongolia.
visa.materials7: Or, for those passing Mongolia in transit, onward ticket and visa for next destination are required.
visa.fees1: Single entry-exit visa - US$25; for urgent service (within a working day) US$50; this kind of Visa is valid for three months from the date of issuing.
visa.fees2: Multiple entry-exit visa valid for six months - $65; for urgent service (within a working day) $130
visa.fees3: Multiple entry-exit visa valid for one year - $13 - $130; for urgent service (within a working day) $26
visa.fees4: Visa extension valid for one week - US$15; for urgent service (within a working day) US$30; US$2 per a day exceeding a week.

seasons.description1: Winter in Mongolia is marked by extreme cold, with temperatures plummeting to -20 to -35°C. The landscape transforms into a pristine snow-covered wonderland, offering a surreal and breathtaking experience.
seasons.description1-1: Despite the harsh conditions, the Mongolian winter presents unique opportunities for cultural immersion, winter sports, and witnessing the resilience of nomadic communities.
seasons.description2: Mongolian spring, spanning from March to May, witnesses temperatures rising from 0 to 20°C. This season unveils a landscape awakening from winter slumber, adorned with vibrant blooms.
seasons.description2-1: Mild weather makes it an ideal time for outdoor activities and cultural exploration, allowing travelers to experience the nomadic way of life against the backdrop of picturesque scenery.
seasons.description3: Mongolian summer, from June to August, graces the land with warm temperatures ranging from 20 to 35°C. The vast steppes and stunning landscapes come alive, providing an ideal season for outdoor adventures and cultural exploration.
seasons.description3-1: The maximum temperature in the Gobi desert during this period can reach +58 degrees. Nomadic communities thrive during these months, showcasing their traditional way of life against the backdrop of lush greenery.
seasons.description4: Autumn in Mongolia, spanning from September to November, embraces temperatures ranging from 5 to 15°C. As the vibrant summer hues gradually fade, the landscapes transform into a mesmerizing canvas of golden and amber tones.
seasons.description4-1: This season offers a unique blend of crisp air and breathtaking scenery, making it an ideal time for cultural exploration and outdoor activities. Nomadic herders prepare for winter, and the autumnal landscapes provide a picturesque backdrop for witnessing traditional Mongolian life.

weather.title: Average weather in Mongolia
weather.text1: Mongolia is known for its highly continental climate, characterized by dramatic temperature extremes and distinct seasonal shifts. Often referred to as "the Land of Blue Sky," the country enjoys approximately 250 sunny days per year, making it one of the sunniest places in the world. With vast, open landscapes and minimal vegetation, Mongolia experiences intense diurnal and annual temperature variations.
weather.text2: From November to March, average temperatures remain below zero across much of the country, and even in April and October, the air stays close to freezing. Winter nights often drop to –40°C, especially in the northern and central regions, with the coldest recorded temperature being –55°C at Lake Uvs. In contrast, summers can be surprisingly hot, with temperatures soaring up to +40°C in the Gobi Desert and reaching around +33°C in Ulaanbaatar, the world’s coldest capital. It’s not uncommon for monthly temperature swings to exceed 45°C in many areas.
weather.text3: Each season in Mongolia offers a unique travel experience. Winters are long, dry, and extremely cold, transforming even the Gobi Desert into a frozen, quiet landscape—a stunning sight for intrepid explorers. Spring is a time of renewal, as temperatures slowly rise and nomadic herders begin migrating to fresh pastures. It’s a beautiful season to witness daily life in the countryside, with wildflowers blooming and livestock grazing under crisp blue skies.
weather.text4: Summer is the peak travel season. With long, warm days and mostly clear skies, it’s ideal for outdoor activities, exploration of Mongolia’s vast steppes and deserts, and cultural experiences like the Naadam Festival. In autumn, the weather gradually cools, and the landscapes are painted in golden hues, creating a serene and photogenic atmosphere perfect for those who enjoy quieter, reflective journeys.
weather.text5: Overall, Mongolia’s climate is defined by contrast—icy winters, hot summers, and rapid shifts in weather. These conditions shape not only the land but also the resilient spirit of its people. For travelers seeking raw natural beauty and a sense of true adventure, Mongolia offers a climate as bold and unforgettable as the landscapes it shapes.

Tours.title: CLASSIC TOURS
Tours.subtitle: TOURS & TRIPS
Tours.group_tours_description: Our Group Tours are designed for small groups of up to 8 travelers, offering a well-balanced, all-inclusive experience with fixed start dates and per-person pricing. Airport transfers, accommodation, meals, transportation, and guiding are all included—no hidden costs. Explore Mongolia's highlights such as the Gobi Desert, alpine lakes, nomadic culture, trekking routes, horseback adventures, and the Altai Mountains. Travel comfortably, meet like-minded explorers, and experience Mongolia's most iconic regions with expert local guides. Secure your place now and come explore Mongolia with us.
Tours.classic_tours_description: Our Classic Tours are designed for travelers who want to experience the very best of Mongolia in a balanced and comfortable way. These itineraries cover iconic regions such as the Gobi Desert, Khangai Mountains, Central Mongolia, and Lake Khuvsgul. Each tour can be fully customized based on your travel dates, group size, interests, and preferred comfort level. Please contact us for a personalized itinerary and a detailed price estimate.
Tours.destinations_description: Our Destination Tours focus on a specific region or travel theme, allowing for deeper exploration and more meaningful experiences. Similar to our Classic Tours, these journeys are fully customizable and can be tailored to your schedule, group size, and interests. Whether you are exploring the Altai Mountains, traveling on horseback, or visiting the land of the reindeer herders, these tours offer authentic and immersive adventures. Contact us for a customized plan and cost estimate.

pricing_info.intro: Our price is all-inclusive and based on a group of 8 - 12 guests.
pricing_info.intro_detail: Please see below for more information in terms of what is included and excluded in the tour package.
pricing_info.included_title: What is included in our price:
included_items: Tour as described (see Attachment 1 for complete details)
Meals during the trip (B, L, D)
pricing_info.excluded_title: What is excluded in our price:
excluded_items: Private Liability, Accident and Travel Insurance
Single Supplement, On-site upgrade of accommodation and vehicle

Tours.text: Traveling to the Mongolia as part of a group has many advantages. You can meet like-minded individuals and make new friends. On top of that, group tours also allow for discounted bundle deals - so you get to enjoy everything Mongolia offer at much more reasonable price.
Tours.main_tour_desc: Although Mongolia is largely covered in endless steppes, the journey also reveals stunning landscapes—lakes, canyons, sand dunes, and dramatic cliffs. Traveling from one province to another often means days of driving across some of the Earth’s roughest and most remote terrain. At times, your only companions are herds of horses and yaks grazing the open plains. At others, eagles circle silently overhead.
Tours.altai_desc: We invite you to discover the majestic mountains, breathtaking landscapes, and rich Kazakh culture of Altai Tavanbogd—the stunning rooftop of Mongolia.

southNorthTour.title: SOUTH - NORTH TOUR
southNorthTour.description: Discover Mongolia’s highlights from the vast South Gobi to the stunning Khuvsgul Lake in the North, and everything amazing in between. A 13-day journey of iconic landscapes, rich culture, and unforgettable adventures.
southNorthTour.detail_description: This 13-day tour is the perfect way to explore Mongolia, from the vast South Gobi—with its striking White Stupa, majestic Khongor Sand Dunes, and fiery Flaming Cliffs—through the scenic Khangai region, where you can relax in natural hot springs and discover the pristine Terkh Lake, all the way to the stunning Lake Khuvsgul in the north. Our tours are fully inclusive with no hidden fees; you only need to bring your sleeping bag, and we take care of everything else. Your safety and comfort are our top priority, and we would be honored to make this journey truly unforgettable. Experience the nomadic way of life with us and create memories that will last a lifetime.

eightLakesTrekking.title: Eight Lakes Trekking Adventure (12 Days 11 Nights)
eightLakesTrekking.description: Embark on an 12-day trekking adventure into Mongolia's wild landscapes. Hike through the Orkhon Valley to the remote Eight Lakes, camp under endless stars, meet nomads, and finish with soothing hot springs and historic Kharkhorin.
eightLakesTrekking.detail_description: This 12-day guided adventure is crafted for hikers seeking Mongolia's untouched beauty. After Naadam festival in Ulaanbaatar, travel to Elsen Tasarkhai and the Orkhon Valley to begin a multi-day trek through forests, valleys, and rugged terrain toward the Eight Lakes. Camp beside alpine lakes beneath star-filled skies; bring only your personal sleeping bag—our team provides tents, meals, logistics, and a support vehicle. After the trek, relax at Tsenkher hot springs and explore ancient Kharkhorin before returning to UB.

eightLakesEquestrian.title: Eight Lakes Equestrian Adventure (10 Days 9 Nights)
eightLakesEquestrian.description: Saddle up for a horseback odyssey across Mongolia's majestic heartland. Ride through the Orkhon Valley to the remote Eight Lakes, canter across ancient trails, camp under starry skies, meet nomadic herders, and conclude with relaxing hot springs and historic Kharkhorin.
eightLakesEquestrian.detail_description: This 10-day guided equestrian adventure is crafted for riders seeking Mongolia's untouched beauty from the saddle. After the Naadam festival in Ulaanbaatar, travel to Elsen Tasarkhai and the Orkhon Valley to begin a five-day horseback expedition. Ride through forests, valleys, and high mountain passes toward the legendary Eight Lakes, covering approximately 15-25 km per day on sturdy Mongolian horses. Camp beside alpine lakes; we provide all riding gear, horses, tack, meals, logistics, and a support vehicle. After your ride, unwind at Tsenkher hot springs and explore ancient Kharkhorin before returning to UB.

altaiExpedition.title: Altai Expedition: Mongolia's West (16 Days / 15 Nights)
altaiExpedition.description: Embark on a 16-day expedition across Mongolia's vast landscapes. From Ulaanbaatar's Naadam Festival to the western Altai peaks, ride horses in Tavan Bogd, meet Kazakh eagle hunters, and camp under starry skies. Return through ancient stone monuments and the historic capital Kharkhorin.
altaiExpedition.detail_description: This 16-day guided journey is crafted for travelers seeking the epic scale and profound contrasts of Mongolia. After the Naadam Festival in Ulaanbaatar, travel from the central dunes of Elsen Tasarkhai to the western frontier. Cross the vast Great Lakes Basin, witness the immense salt lake of Khyargas Nuur, and delve into the heart of the Altai Tavan Bogd National Park. Here, ride sturdy horses, hike glacial valleys, and connect with Kazakh eagle-hunting traditions. Camp under endless starry skies and in authentic family homes, with our team handling all logistics, meals, and transportation in rugged 4x4 vehicles. After exploring ancient stone monuments on the steppe and revisiting the historic capital of Kharkhorin, return to Ulaanbaatar with a deep understanding of Mongolia's majestic landscapes and enduring cultures.

tourList.title: CITY TOUR
tourList.description: Ulaanbaatar can be a bit challenging to navigate on your own, but with an experienced guide, you can make the most of your visit—exploring world-class museums, enjoying traditional performances, tasting international cuisine, and shopping for fine cashmere. The city stays alive until 3 a.m., offering vibrant nightlife and unique local experiences. Constantly evolving, Ulaanbaatar might just be the most unexpected highlight of your Mongolian adventure.

tourList.title: CENTRAL AIMAG TOUR
tourList.description: Mongolia’s environment remains remarkably well-preserved, thanks to its vast natural landscapes, late urban development, and a traditional nomadic lifestyle rooted in resource conservation and deep respect for nature. Spiritual beliefs and harmony with the land continue to shape daily life. By choosing the Central Tour, you'll experience the best of both worlds—the vibrant city and the serene countryside—making your journey truly unforgettable.

tourList.title: KHUVSGUL LAKE TOUR
tourList.description: Khuvsgul Lake is a deep, clear, and pristine freshwater lake in northern Mongolia—one of the largest in Asia. Known for its stunning blue water, it's perfect for relaxing, hiking, horseback riding, and soaking in untouched natural beauty. A true gem of Mongolia.

tourList.title: TRIP TO THE GOBI DESERT
tourList.description: Gobi is famous for its sand dunes, mountains, and rare animals such as snow leopards and Bactrian camels. The Khongoryn Els sand dunes in Gobi Gurvansaikhan National Park are said to "sing" when the wind blows. The Gobi is also best known for the dinosaur fossils found on the red flaming cliffs of Bayanzag.

individualList.title: HORSE RIDING TOUR
individualList.description: Across Mongolia—even just outside Ulaanbaatar—horseback riding tours offer an unforgettable way to explore the country. Ride through vast landscapes, experience nomadic heritage, and connect with Mongolia’s unique traditions. It’s the perfect journey for lasting memories.

individualList.title: REINDEER HERDERS LAND
individualList.description: We invite you on a journey into Mongolia’s remote Taiga to discover the unique culture of the Tsaatan people, surrounded by some of the country’s most pristine natural beauty. Get ready for an unforgettable adventure—and yes, you’ll even ride a reindeer!

Tours.altai_tour_text: Altai Tavan Bogd is one of Mongolia’s most breathtaking natural wonders. At its heart stands the snow-capped Khüiten Uul, the highest peak in Mongolia at 4,374 meters (14,201 ft), and the tallest of the five sacred peaks that give the Tavan Bogd Mountains—literally “Five Saints”—their name. The national park spans 630,000 hectares and is home to three large freshwater lakes, 34 glaciers, and several waterfalls. The largest glacier, Potanin, covers 23 km². The Tavan Bogd Mountains hold deep spiritual significance for local Kazakh, Tuvan, and Mongolian communities. The park stretches along the Russian and Chinese borders, following the Altai Mountain Range where Mongolia, Russia, China, and Kazakhstan meet. Rich in history, the region features tens of thousands of ancient petroglyphs, now part of a UNESCO World Heritage Site, along with Turkic stone statues and burial mounds—evidence of the many ancient tribes who once held ceremonies here. The best time to visit is from June to October, when the weather is milder and tour camps are active. August and September are particularly popular for mountain climbing and coincide with eagle festivals, drawing visitors who combine cultural experiences with nature travel. Winter brings its own adventures, including snow skiing and traditional eagle hunting. Whether you're interested in day hikes, horseback riding, or camping under starry skies, Altai Tavan Bogd offers unforgettable experiences year-round.
Tours.altai_tour_text2: Contact us to learn more about this incredible destination!
Tours.horse_tour_text: Whether deep in the countryside or just outside Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia offers unforgettable horseback riding tours. Riding through the vast, green steppes is the perfect way to truly experience the spirit of Mongolia. There’s nothing quite like the feeling of moving as one with your horse across the endless grasslands—it’s a connection to nature, freedom, and centuries of nomadic tradition. On horseback, you’ll discover the rich history of Mongolia’s nomadic lifestyle, breathtaking natural beauty, and unique cultural heritage. To share this magical experience, our travel agency has crafted a special tour designed for daytime horseback riding and peaceful stargazing at night. We warmly invite you to join us on this thrilling and immersive journey. Contact us to begin your adventure!
Tours.reindeer_tour_text: The Tsaatan are among the last remaining nomadic reindeer herders in the world, living deep in the remote forests near Lake Khuvsgul in northern Mongolia. With their unique way of life and close bond with nature, they preserve traditions that have been passed down for centuries. This is a rare and unforgettable opportunity to meet the Tsaatan people, learn about their customs, and even ride a reindeer through Mongolia’s untouched wilderness. Surrounded by breathtaking landscapes, you’ll experience a way of life that few in the world ever see. Let us help you connect with this extraordinary culture and create a once-in-a-lifetime journey into the heart of Mongolia’s nomadic heritage. Contact us to make it happen!

Khangai.description: Although the continental country is mostly covered in steppes, you'll also see wondrous sights like lakes, canyons, sand dunes, and cliffs along the way. Getting from one province to another requires days of driving over some of the roughest terrain on Earth, often across vast empty spaces. Sometimes your only companions on the road are the herds of horses, yaks and sheep grazing on the plains. At other times, eagles are seen hovering above.
Khangai.day1text: Baga Gazriin Chuluu is located 230 km south of Ulaanbaatar and 37 km northwest of Delgertsogt town in Dundgobi province, mostly accessible via paved roads. This granite mountain zone rises up to 200 meters and spans 300 sq.km, with Takhilgat Peak reaching 1768 m. The area features streams, aspen groves, and rich historical remains—from Bronze Age tombs and rock carvings to ruins of 17th–19th century temples. Wildlife like wild sheep and ibex roam its canyons, while the wind-sculpted rock formations offer excellent opportunities for hiking, bouldering, and camping.
Khangai.schedule1-5: After 15:00 - Time to enjoy and hike
Khangai.day2text: Tsagaan Suvarga, or the White Stupa, is a striking cliff formation in southwestern Dundgobi province. Once an ancient seabed, its layered sedimentary structure formed over millions of years. The 60-meter-high escarpment stretches over 400 meters and faces east, glowing beautifully at sunrise. From afar, it resembles the ruins of an ancient city. During storms, animals sometimes fall from its sheer cliffs. After heavy rain, water cascades down the face like a dramatic waterfall.
Khangai.day3text: Yolyn Am, or the Valley of the Vultures, is a deep, narrow gorge in the Zuun Saikhanii Nuruu range of southern Mongolia’s Gurvan Saikhan Mountains. Named after the Lammergeier (Yol in Mongolian), this dramatic valley lies in the arid Gobi Desert yet is known for its unexpected ice field. By winter’s end, the ice can be several meters thick and stretch for kilometers. While it once lasted year-round, today it typically melts by September. It is also a great place to spot eagles, wild argali sheep and golden eagles.
Khangai.day4text: Hongoriin Els, or the Khongor Sand Dunes are among the largest and most striking in Mongolia, stretching 180 km in length, up to 8 km wide, and towering as high as 200 meters. They rise dramatically between the Altai Mountains to the south and lush oases and streams to the north. Climbing the dunes is a rewarding challenge—not only for the stunning views from the top but also for the unique "singing" sound the sand makes under your feet.
Khangai.schedule4-5: After 15:30 - Climb the sand dunes and ride a camel
Khangai.day5text: Bayanzag, also known as the Flaming Cliffs, is famous for its red clay formations sculpted by wind and rain over thousands of years. The name Bayanzag means "rich in saxaul," referring to the native desert tree that grows here. In 1922, American paleontologist Roy Chapman Andrews and his team accidentally discovered dinosaur fossils while searching for traces of ancient humans. Their find—dinosaur bones and the world’s first dinosaur eggs—put Bayanzag on the world map as a major paleontological site.
Khangai.day6text: Ongiin Hiid - the Ongi Monastery was once one of the largest monastic complexes in the Gobi Desert, spread across both banks of the Ongi River and linked by a bridge. The southern side housed Hutagt Monastery, founded over 320 years ago with 9 main temples, while Balim Monastery on the north was built about 240 years ago with 13 temples. At its peak, Ongi had four religious schools and over 1,000 monks. Sadly, it was destroyed during the 1930s communist purges, leaving only a stupa. Monastic life resumed in 1990, and a small temple was rebuilt in 2004.
Khangai.day7text: Kharkhorin, the first capital of the Mongol Empire, was founded by Genghis Khan in 1206. It served as Mongolia’s center for 32 years and thrived as a major trade and religious hub for 140 years. In the 1580s, the first temple of Erdene Zuu Monastery was built on its ruins by order of the Dalai Lama. By the late 1700s, the site included 62 temples and over 500 structures. Today, Erdene Zuu is a UNESCO-registered heritage site.
Khangai.schedule7-5: After 16:00 - Visit Kharkhorin museum and Erdenezuu Monastery
Khangai.day8text: Tsenkher Hot Springs, Mongolia’s most renowned natural spa, lies 27 km south of Tsetserleg in Arkhangai province. Surrounded by forested hills and rugged mountains, the springs emerge at 85.5°C and are believed to ease joint and nerve conditions. Rich in minerals like hydrogen sulfide and sodium carbonate, Tsenkher offers both indoor and outdoor baths in a tranquil valley setting—perfect for relaxation and rejuvenation.
Khangai.attention_desc: Pack the essentials for the hot springs—swimsuit and beachwear.
Khangai.schedule8-5: After 14:30 - Soak in and enjoy the hot springs
Khangai.day9text: Terkh White Lake, or Terkhiin Tsagaan Nuur, is a breathtaking freshwater volcanic lake located in Arkhangai Province, about 675 km west of Ulaanbaatar. Formed thousands of years ago when lava from the Khorgo volcano blocked the Terkh River, the lake now sits at an elevation of 2,060 meters above sea level. It stretches 16 km in length, spans 4–10 km in width, and reaches a maximum depth of 28 meters, with an average of around 20 meters. Surrounded by volcanic mountains and rolling grasslands, Terkh White Lake is known for its crystal-clear waters and serene atmosphere, making it a favorite spot for hiking, photography, and relaxation. It remains one of Mongolia’s most cherished natural wonders.
Khangai.day10text: On our journey to Lake Khuvsgul, we’ll stop halfway for an overnight stay in Ider Sum—with the option to camp if the weather permits. Nestled in a tranquil valley, Ider Sum provides a peaceful and scenic rest spot, offering a refreshing break between long days of travel through Mongolia’s vast landscapes.
Khangai.day11text: Khuvsgul Nuur, or Lake Khuvsgul, located at 1,645 m on Mongolia’s northern border with the Siberian Taiga, is the country’s largest freshwater lake and second largest by surface area at 2,760 sq km. It stretches 136 km long and 36 km wide, with a maximum depth of 262 m. Fed by over 90 rivers, it drains south via the Egiin Gol River, which eventually flows into Siberia’s Lake Baikal. Holding 70% of Mongolia’s freshwater and 1-2% of the world’s, Khovsgol Lake is incredibly clear—its water is as blue and transparent as the Caribbean. Imagine spending your holiday by this stunning, pristine lake.
Khangai.schedule11-5: After 15:30 - Truly enjoy the scenery, hike, explore and bathe
Khangai.schedule11-6: Around 17:30 - Visit the Wishing Rock island
Khangai.day12text: Today, we begin our journey back to the capital city. Along the way, we stop in Bulgan, a town long known to travelers as a convenient overnight stop between Ulaanbaatar and the popular Khuvsgul Lake. If you’ve been exploring central or southern Mongolia, Bulgan may surprise you with its lush conifer forests, charming log cabins, and the noticeable absence of traditional gers—offering a different glimpse into Mongolian life and landscape.
Khangai.day13text: We’ll continue our drive back to Ulaanbaatar, stopping for lunch along the way. Arrival is expected around 15:00, depending on traffic. This marks the end of the tour, with the rest of the day free to relax or explore the city. In the evening, we’ll enjoy a farewell dinner to celebrate the journey.
Khangai.schedule13-5: After 15:30 - Time to relax, explore UB on your own

City.picture_text: ULAANBAATAR CITY and TERELJ NATIONAL PARK TOUR - 2 days 1 night
City.description: Ulaanbaatar and its surrounding natural sights can be a bit challenging to navigate, but with the help of an experienced guide, you can enjoy everything from world-class museums and traditional theater to international cuisine and cashmere shopping. Just a short drive away, Terelj National Park offers a peaceful escape into Mongolia’s stunning landscapes, with scenic valleys, rock formations, and nomadic culture. This combination of city life and nature makes for a perfect introduction to modern Mongolia—especially for those with limited time.
City.day1text: Explore the stunning Terelj National Park, home to the iconic Turtle Rock and the towering Chinggis Khan Equestrian Statue. Enjoy a short hike to Aryabal Monastery, go horseback riding through scenic landscapes, and experience an overnight stay in a traditional Mongolian ger. Savor authentic khorkhog, along with international cuisine, for a rich and memorable adventure.
City.day2text: Discover Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia’s vibrant capital city. Begin at Sukhbaatar Square, then explore your museum of choice—Chinggis Khan Museum, Zanabazar Museum of Art, Bogd Khan Palace Museum, or the Natural History Museum, home to a complete Tarbosaurus skeleton. Visit the spiritual Gandan Monastery and enjoy panoramic views from the Zaisan Monument. Along the way, stop for coffee and lunch at local favorites, and end the day with a delicious dinner in the city.

Khuvsgul.description: Khuvsgul Lake, often called the "Asian Switzerland" and the "Blue Pearl of Asia," sits at 1,645 meters above sea level. Stretching 136 km in length and reaching depths of 262 meters, it is the second most voluminous freshwater lake in Asia. Remarkably, it holds nearly 70% of Mongolia’s fresh water and 0.4% of the world’s supply. The journey to Khuvsgul is just as breathtaking, guiding you through Mongolia’s diverse and beautiful landscapes, making the trip an unforgettable experience in itself.
Khuvsgul.day1text: Elsen Tasarkhai, often called the "Little Gobi," lies about 280 km west of Ulaanbaatar. It is part of the Mongol Els sand dunes, stretching across Tuv, Uvurkhangai, and Bulgan provinces before merging with the Khugnu Khan mountain range. Spanning 80 km, the dunes offer a stunning blend of desert, steppe, and mountain scenery. The area is ideal for relaxation, with golden sands, rare bushes, rivers, and nearby forested patches creating a peaceful and diverse landscape. Enjoy a traditional Mongolian dinner and spend the night in a cozy ger.
Khuvsgul.schedule1-4: Around 14:00 - Arrival at the Little Gobi
Khuvsgul.schedule1-5: Around 14:00 - Time to enjoy and climb the dunes
Khuvsgul.day2text: Tsenkher Hot Spring is located south of Tsetserleg town in Arkhangai Province. The spring water rises under high pressure from deep underground and remains uncontaminated by surface water due to its naturally high temperature. It maintains a strong, steady flow of up to 10 liters per second, offering a refreshing and therapeutic experience. Get ready to soak and relax.
Khuvsgul.att_desc1: Pack the essentials for the hot springs—swimsuit and beachwear.
Khuvsgul.day3text: Terkhiin Tsagaan Nuur - Terkh White Lake is located in Arkhangai Province, approximately 675 km west of Ulaanbaatar. This freshwater, volcanogenic lake stretches 16 km from west to east and is about 6 km wide from north to south. The lake was formed when a 40-50 cm thick basaltic lava flow from the eruption of Khorgiin Togoo and other nearby volcanoes blocked the course of the Terkhiin River, creating a natural dam. A great spot to dive in and refresh. Hiking the nearby Khorgo volcano or surrounding mountains rewards you with stunning views.
Khuvsgul.schedule3-4: Around 15:00 - Time to hike, sweat and bathe
Khuvsgul.day4text: On our journey to Lake Khuvsgul, we’ll stop halfway for an overnight stay in Ider Sum—with the option to camp if weather allows. Nestled in a scenic valley, Ider Sum offers a peaceful break surrounded by beautiful landscapes. Relax in cozy accommodations, enjoy warm Mongolian hospitality, and savor local cuisine as you unwind in nature’s calm embrace.
Khuvsgul.day5text: Khuvsgul Lake lies at the heart of Mongolia’s most stunning province, surrounded by dense forests, sparkling rivers, and rugged mountains. Often called the “Blue Pearl of Mongolia,” the lake is crystal clear and deeply tranquil. Every curve of its shoreline reveals a new natural wonder, offering endless opportunities for reflection, exploration, and connection with untouched wilderness. Khuvsgul is a true haven for nature lovers, where the beauty of Mongolia shines at its purest.
Khuvsgul.schedule5-4: Around 13:30 - Arrival at the lake camp
Khuvsgul.schedule5-5: After 14:00 - Explore and enjoy the lake Khuvsgul
Khuvsgul.day6text: Today, we begin our journey back to the capital city. Along the way, we stop in Bulgan, a town long known to travelers as a convenient overnight stop between Ulaanbaatar and the popular Khuvsgul Lake. If you’ve been exploring central or southern Mongolia, Bulgan may surprise you with its lush conifer forests, charming log cabins, and the noticeable absence of traditional gers—offering a different glimpse into Mongolian life and landscape.
Khuvsgul.day7text: We’ll continue our drive back to Ulaanbaatar, stopping for lunch along the way. Arrival is expected around 15:00, depending on traffic. This marks the end of the tour, with the rest of the day free to relax or explore the city. In the evening, we’ll enjoy a farewell dinner to celebrate the journey.

Gobi.description: The Gobi is renowned for its vast sand dunes, rugged mountains, and rare wildlife, including snow leopards and two-humped Bactrian camels. In Gobi Gurvansaikhan National Park, the towering Khongoryn Els dunes are known to "sing" as the wind moves across them, while the Yolyn Am canyon surprises visitors with its deep ice fields even in summer. The region is also famous for the Flaming Cliffs of Bayanzag, where groundbreaking dinosaur fossils were first discovered. This route is one of Mongolia’s most iconic and popular journeys among travelers.
Gobi.day1text: Tsagaan Suvarga, or The White Stupa, is a stunning natural formation in the Gobi Desert, known for its dramatic, eroded limestone cliffs that resemble ancient city ruins. Standing up to 30 meters high and stretching over 400 meters, the cliffs display beautiful layers of white, pink, and orange hues, especially vibrant at sunrise and sunset. Shaped by millions of years of wind and weather, Tsagaan Suvarga offers a surreal and unforgettable landscape that captures the quiet majesty of the Mongolian desert.
Gobi.schedule1-4: Around 15:00 - Arrival at the White Stupa
Gobi.day2text: Yoliin Am, or the Yol Valley, nestled in the Gobi Gurvansaikhan Mountains, is a deep, narrow gorge famous for its year-round ice field and dramatic cliffs. It’s a great place to spot wildlife, including ibex, wild argali sheep, golden eagles, and eagles, offering a stunning and peaceful escape in the heart of the Gobi Desert.
Gobi.day3text: Hongoriin Els, famously known as the "Singing Dunes," are among Mongolia’s largest and most impressive sand formations. Rising up to 300 meters high and stretching for miles across the Gobi Desert, these vast dunes create a breathtaking landscape. When the wind blows, the sands produce a unique humming sound, adding a magical touch to this natural wonder. Visitors can explore the dunes by camel or on foot, making it a must-see destination in Mongolia.
Gobi.schedule3-5: After 16:30 - Time to climb the dunes
Gobi.day4text: Bayanzag, also known as the Flaming Cliffs, is a striking red sandstone formation stretching 5 km wide and about 8 km long. Its fiery hues glow brilliantly at sunrise and sunset. In 1922, American paleontologist Roy Chapman Andrews made groundbreaking discoveries here, unearthing dinosaur bones and eggs that revealed ancient life hidden within Mongolia’s desert sands.
Gobi.day5text: Baga Gazriin Chuluu is a rugged granite massif rising dramatically from the surrounding steppe in southern Mongolia. Known for its striking rock formations, caves, and ancient petroglyphs, it offers a unique blend of natural beauty and cultural history. There is much to explore, including the nearby Poplar Rock Valley, known locally as Sudutyn. The area is popular for hiking, rock climbing, and discovering peaceful wilderness.
Gobi.schedule5-5: After 17:00 - time to enjoy, take photos and go hiking.
Gobi.day6text: This day, we head to Terelj National Park, just a short drive from Ulaanbaatar. Explore the stunning park, home to the iconic Turtle Rock. Enjoy a short hike to Aryabal Monastery, go horseback riding through scenic landscapes, and spend the night in a traditional ger. Savor authentic khorkhog along with international cuisine for a memorable experience.
Gobi.schedule6-4: Around 15:00 - Arrival in Terelj, visit Turtle Rock
Gobi.day7text: We’ll drive back to Ulaanbaatar, stopping to visit the impressive Chinggis Khan Equestrian Statue along the way. Depending on traffic, we expect to arrive in the city right around lunchtime for a meal. This marks the end of the tour, leaving the rest of the day free to relax or explore. In the evening, we’ll gather for a farewell dinner to celebrate the journey.
Gobi.schedule7-4: After 14:00 - Enjoy the city on your own

Central.description: Mongolia’s environment remains well-preserved, thanks to its vast natural landscapes, late urban development, and a traditional nomadic lifestyle that values resourcefulness and harmony with nature. The Central Tour offers a perfect blend of city life and countryside beauty—making your journey truly unforgettable.
Central.day1text: Elsen Tasarkhai, often called the "Little Gobi," lies about 280 km west of Ulaanbaatar. It is part of the Mongol Els sand dunes, stretching across Tuv, Uvurkhangai, and Bulgan provinces before merging with the Khugnu Khan mountain range. Spanning 80 km, the dunes offer a stunning blend of desert, steppe, and mountain scenery. The area is ideal for relaxation, with golden sands, rare bushes, rivers, and nearby forested patches creating a peaceful and diverse landscape. Enjoy a traditional Mongolian dinner and spend the night in a cozy ger.
Central.schedule1-5: 14:00 - Time to enjoy, hike and explore.
Central.day2text: Tsenkher Hot Spring is located south of Tsetserleg town in Arkhangai Province. The spring water rises under high pressure from deep underground and remains uncontaminated by surface water due to its naturally high temperature. It maintains a strong, steady flow of up to 10 liters per second, offering a refreshing and therapeutic experience.
Central.att_desc2: Pack the essentials for the hot springs—swimsuit and beachwear.
Central.schedule2-5: 15:00 - Time to enjoy, relax and soak in the hot springs
Central.day3text: Visit Kharkhorin, the ancient capital of the Mongol Empire. Founded by Genghis Khan in 1206, it served as Mongolia’s political and cultural center for 32 years and remained influential for 140 years. Once a major trading hub, it was home to diverse temples and connected East and West. Then explore Lake Ugii in Arkhangai Province, a calm freshwater lake popular with both locals and tourists. Measuring 8 km long, 6 km wide, and 7 meters deep, it's ideal for fishing, birdwatching, and peaceful relaxation.
Central.schedule3-4: Around 13:00 - Visit Kharkhorin and ErdeneZuu Monastry
Central.schedule3-7: After 19:00 - Time to relax and enjoy the lake
Central.day4text: Terelj is a striking mountain area just outside Ulaanbaatar, known for its dramatic rock formations and scenic valleys framed by steep, forested slopes. A highlight is the iconic Turtle Rock, a natural formation resembling a giant turtle. Nearby, Aryabal Monastery sits peacefully on a hillside, inviting visitors to climb its 108 symbolic steps for panoramic views. Popular among both tourists and locals, Terelj also offers horse and camel rides, making it a perfect blend of nature, culture, and adventure.
Central.schedule4-4: Around 15:00 - Arrival at Turtle Rock, Terelj National Park
Central.day5text: Today, we’ll drive back to Ulaanbaatar, stopping for lunch along the way. We expect to arrive around 3:00 PM. This marks the end of the tour— the rest of the day is yours to relax, explore the city, or enjoy at your own pace.

EightLakesEquestrian.day1text: Today is all about experiencing Mongolia's famous Naadam Festival. Your regular tickets are included in the tour package. After the opening ceremony, we'll explore the lively festivities—a perfect opportunity to see locals in their finest traditional clothing, witness the country's biggest holiday in full swing, and taste iconic treats like Huushuur and, for the adventurous, Airag, fermented mare's milk.
EightLakesEquestrian.day2text: Travel to the beautiful Elsen Tasarkhai dunes, a unique stretch of desert surrounded by steppe and mountains. Enjoy a peaceful camel ride across golden sands and take in Mongolia's dramatic landscape contrasts. Overnight in a ger camp surrounded by serene desert silence.
EightLakesEquestrian.day3: Day 3. Stay with Nomadic Family in the Orkhon Valley
EightLakesEquestrian.day3text: Journey into the UNESCO-listed Orkhon Valley, home to centuries of nomadic tradition. We will visit the magnificent Orkhon Waterfall, where the river plunges over a volcanic basalt cliff, creating a powerful spectacle in the middle of the vast grassland. Spend the night with a herder family for an authentic experience — from tending animals to sharing home-cooked meals — and learn firsthand how nomads live in harmony with nature. This intimate stay is often one of the most memorable moments of the trip.
EightLakesEquestrian.day4to8: Day 4–8. Eight Lakes Horseback Riding Expedition
EightLakesEquestrian.day4to8text: Begin your five-day horseback journey into the volcanic highlands of the Eight Lakes region. Each day, you'll ride approximately 15-25 km on sure-footed local horses, following ancient herder trails that weave through wildflower meadows, past ancient lava fields, and over forested ridges. Your destination is the chain of pristine alpine lakes—Shireet, Khaliut, Bugat, Shanaa, Duruu, Khaya, Khuis, and Onon—perched between 2,400–2,600 meters. Experience the rhythm of nomadic travel: mornings saddling up with your guide, days spent traversing vast, untouched landscapes, and evenings setting up camp beside mirror-still lakes under endless stars. Our support vehicle transports all camp gear and luggage, allowing you to ride freely. This immersive riding section is the heart of the tour—connecting you to the land in the traditional Mongolian way.
EightLakesEquestrian.day9text: Relax in natural hot springs surrounded by forested hills. After days of horseback riding, the warm mineral waters offer a soothing and rejuvenating experience for your muscles. Enjoy free time, optional spa services, or exploring the area—a perfect recovery day before the final stretch of your journey.
EightLakesEquestrian.day10text: Visit the ancient capital Kharkhorin and the renowned Erdene Zuu Monastery, Mongolia's first Buddhist temple complex. Explore the rich history of the Mongol Empire before returning to Ulaanbaatar. In the evening, we will enjoy a farewell dinner together to celebrate a successful journey and new friendships.

EightLakesTrekking.day1text: Today is all about experiencing Mongolia's famous Naadam Festival. Your regular tickets are included in the tour package. After the opening ceremony, we'll explore the lively festivities—a perfect opportunity to see locals in their finest traditional clothing, witness the country's biggest holiday in full swing, and taste iconic treats like Huushuur and, for the adventurous, Airag, fermented mare's milk.
EightLakesTrekking.day2text: Travel to the beautiful Elsen Tasarkhai dunes, a unique stretch of desert surrounded by steppe and mountains. Enjoy a peaceful camel ride across golden sands and take in Mongolia's dramatic landscape contrasts. Overnight in a ger camp surrounded by serene desert silence.
EightLakesTrekking.day3: Day 3. Stay with Nomadic Family in the Orkhon Valley
EightLakesTrekking.day3text: Journey into the UNESCO-listed Orkhon Valley, home to centuries of nomadic tradition. We will visit the magnificent Orkhon Waterfall, where the river plunges over a volcanic basalt cliff, creating a powerful spectacle in the middle of the vast grassland. Spend the night with a herder family for an authentic experience — from tending animals to sharing home-cooked meals — and learn firsthand how nomads live in harmony with nature. This intimate stay is often one of the most memorable moments of the trip.
EightLakesTrekking.day4to10text: Begin your multi-day trekking adventure through the volcanic region known for the Eight Lakes (Shireet, Khaliut, Bugat, Shanaa, Duruu, Khaya, Khuis, Onon). Formed centuries ago by volcanic eruptions, the lakes lie in hidden mountain valleys, connected underground and perched at breathtaking elevations above 2,400–2,600 meters. Each day's hike brings new scenery — wildflower meadows, ancient lava fields, forested ridges, clear alpine lakes, and wide-open wilderness. Enjoy campfires under star-filled skies, peaceful mornings beside mirror-calm lakes, and the deep freedom of remote nature. Guests carry only personal necessities; our support team manages the rest with a vehicle ensuring comfort and safety. Note: A personal sleeping bag is not included, but we are happy to help organize one upon request. This trekking section is the highlight of the tour — immersive, pristine, and unforgettable.
EightLakesTrekking.day11text: Relax in natural hot springs surrounded by forested hills. After days of trekking, the warm mineral waters offer a soothing and rejuvenating experience. Enjoy free time, optional spa services, or exploring the area. A perfect recovery day before the final stretch.
EightLakesTrekking.day12text: Visit the ancient capital Kharkhorin and the renowned Erdene Zuu Monastery, Mongolia's first Buddhist temple complex. Explore the rich history of the Mongol Empire before returning to Ulaanbaatar. In the evening, we will enjoy a farewell dinner together to celebrate a successful journey and new friendships.

SouthNorth.day1text: Today is all about experiencing Mongolia's famous Naadam Festival. Your regular tickets are included in the tour package. After the opening ceremony, we'll explore the lively festivities—a perfect opportunity to see locals in their finest traditional clothing, witness the country's biggest holiday in full swing, and taste iconic treats like Huushuur and, for the adventurous, Airag, fermented mare's milk.
SouthNorth.day2text: Tsagaan Suvarga, or the White Stupa, is a breathtaking limestone formation in the Gobi Desert. Its 30-meter cliffs glow in layers of white, pink, and orange, shaped over millions of years by wind and weather. This surreal landscape perfectly captures the quiet majesty of Mongolia. Tonight, we'll overnight with a genuine nomad family, sharing warmth, stories, and laughter under a star-filled sky. Experience their daily life up close—you might milk a cow or join in simple nomadic chores for an unforgettable cultural immersion.
SouthNorth.day3text: We begin our drive toward the Khongor Sand Dunes, stopping at Yoliin Am, or Yol Valley, nestled in the Gobi Gurvansaikhan Mountains. This deep, narrow gorge is famous for its year-round ice field and dramatic cliffs, offering excellent opportunities to spot wildlife such as ibex, wild argali sheep, and golden eagles. Upon arrival at Khongor Sand Dunes, we'll enjoy dinner and overnight at the foot of these majestic dunes in a comfortable ger camp.
SouthNorth.day4text: Khongoriin Els or Khongor Sand dunes - famously known as the "Singing Dunes," is one of Mongolia's largest and most impressive sand formations. Rising up to 300 meters high and stretching for miles across the Gobi Desert, these dunes create a breathtaking landscape. When the wind blows, the sands produce a unique humming sound, adding a magical touch. Explore the dunes on foot or by camel for a truly memorable desert experience.
SouthNorth.day5text: Bayanzag, or the Flaming Cliffs, is a striking red sandstone formation stretching 5 km wide and 8 km long. Its fiery hues glow brilliantly at sunrise and sunset. In 1922, American paleontologist Roy Chapman Andrews made groundbreaking discoveries here, unearthing dinosaur bones and the world's first dinosaur eggs, revealing ancient life hidden within Mongolia's desert sands.
SouthNorth.day6text: Ongiin Hiid, the Ongi Monastery, was once one of the largest monastic complexes in the Gobi Desert. Spread across both banks of the Ongi River, it once housed over 1,000 monks and multiple temples. Destroyed during the 1930s communist purges, only a stupa remains today, though monastic life resumed in 1990 and a small temple was rebuilt in 2004. Tonight, we'll camp under the stars and cook our meal over an open fire, embracing the raw beauty and silence of the Gobi.
SouthNorth.day7text: Kharkhorin, founded by Genghis Khan in 1206, was the first capital of the Mongol Empire, serving as a major trade and religious hub. The nearby Erdene Zuu Monastery, built in the late 16th century, grew to include 62 temples and over 500 structures. Today, Erdene Zuu is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a fascinating glimpse into Mongolia's rich spiritual and cultural history.
SouthNorth.day8text: Tsenkher Hot Springs, or Tsenkheriin Rashaan, is Mongolia's most famous natural spa. Surrounded by forested hills and rugged mountains, the springs emerge at 85.5°C and are rich in minerals believed to ease joint and nerve conditions. Relax in indoor or outdoor baths amid this tranquil valley setting.
SouthNorth.attention_desc: Don't forget to pack your swimsuit and beachwear!
SouthNorth.day9text: Terkh White Lake, or Terkhiin Tsagaan Nuur, is a stunning freshwater volcanic lake formed when lava from Khorgo volcano blocked the Terkh River. Surrounded by volcanic mountains and rolling grasslands, it stretches 16 km long, 4–10 km wide, and reaches a depth of up to 28 meters. Known for its crystal-clear waters and serene atmosphere, the lake is perfect for hiking, photography, and relaxation.
SouthNorth.day10text: Today, we drive north, arriving in the evening at Lake Khuvsgul. Along the way, we can stop at scenic spots and enjoy the vastness and beauty of the Khangai region.
SouthNorth.day11text: Khuvsgul Nuur, Mongolia's largest freshwater lake, sits at 1,645 m above sea level along the northern border with Siberia. Stretching 136 km long and 36 km wide, its waters are as clear and blue as the Caribbean. Spend the day enjoying the lake's pristine beauty, surrounded by Siberian forests and stunning mountain landscapes.
SouthNorth.day12text: On our way back to Ulaanbaatar, we visit Uran Togoo, an extinct volcano famed for its perfectly circular crater. A 2-hour hike to the top offers spectacular panoramic views. Later, we'll camp under a starry sky, relax by the campfire, and prepare Khorkhog, Mongolia's famous BBQ cooked with hot stones, for dinner—a truly hands-on and unforgettable experience.
SouthNorth.day13text: We continue our drive to Ulaanbaatar, stopping for lunch along the way. Arrival is expected around 15:00 in the afternoon, depending on traffic. The rest of the day is free to relax or explore the city at your own pace. In the evening, we'll gather for a farewell dinner to celebrate the journey and the friendships made along the way.

AltaiExpedition.day1text: Begin your Mongolian adventure with the country's greatest celebration: the Naadam Festival. Experience the excitement of wrestling matches, horse races on the open steppe, and skilled archers. This vibrant day provides a powerful introduction to Mongolia's proud traditions. Dinner and overnight in a hotel.
AltaiExpedition.day2text: Ride a camel across the golden dunes of Elsen Tasarkhai, a desert landscape where sand meets grassland. Continue to Kharkhorin, the historic heart of the Mongol Empire. Visit the magnificent Erdene Zuu Monastery before spending the night with a local nomadic herder family.
AltaiExpedition.day3text: A day to unwind and relax. Soak in natural hot springs set among forested hills and fresh mountain air. The warm, mineral-rich water is perfect for soothing tired muscles and offers a peaceful retreat for your body and mind. Dinner and overnight in a comfortable ger camp.
AltaiExpedition.day4text: Your journey to western Mongolia begins. Travel deep into the country's interior, watching the landscape shift from rolling steppe to distant mountains. With long open roads, endless skies, and quiet villages, you'll feel the vastness and remoteness of the land. Dinner and overnight in a comfortable ger camp near Tosontsengel.
AltaiExpedition.day5text: Enter the Great Lakes Basin and arrive at the beautiful Khar Nuur. Its calm waters mirror the wide sky and surrounding hills. This peaceful lakeside setting introduces the unique landscapes of western Mongolia, where water, desert, and steppe exist side by side. Dinner and overnight in a comfortable ger camp.
AltaiExpedition.day6text: Explore the immense Khyargas Nuur, a vast salt lake stretching across the desert steppe. Here, silence feels infinite. Camp in tents under a sky full of stars for your first true wilderness night—far from towns, noise, and modern life. Dinner and overnight in a tent by the lake.
AltaiExpedition.day7text: Arrive in Khovd, a provincial capital in western Mongolia. Enjoy the comfort of a local hotel, hot meals, and time to rest. Stroll through the town, resupply, and observe daily life shaped by trade, tradition, and the surrounding mountains. Dinner and overnight in a hotel.
AltaiExpedition.day8text: Travel to Bayan-Ölgii, Mongolia's westernmost province and home to Kazakh culture. The landscape grows more dramatic as the Altai Mountains rise ahead. Stay near Tsengel village and experience the shift in language, customs, and hospitality. Dinner and overnight in a comfortable guest house with private facilities.
AltaiExpedition.day9: Days 9–11 – Altai Tavan Bogd National Park
AltaiExpedition.day9text: Immerse yourself in the majestic Altai Mountains. Over three days, explore this pristine wilderness of towering peaks, vast glaciers, and sweeping valleys. Navigate the landscape on sturdy Mongolian horses, trek to the immense Potanin Glacier on foot, and discover ancient rock carvings left by early nomads. Spend time with local Kazakh eagle-hunting families, learning how their ancient traditions thrive in this rugged terrain. Your days blend horseback riding, hiking, and cultural connection, while nights are spent camping under clear skies or in a Kazakh family's home, surrounded by profound peace.
AltaiExpedition.day12text: Return to Ölgii town after days in the mountains. Enjoy the comforts of a hotel, hot showers, and warm meals. Take time to rest, reflect, and appreciate the remote and powerful landscapes you've journeyed through. Dinner and overnight in a hotel.
AltaiExpedition.day13text: Begin the long journey eastward. Drive across dramatic terrain where mountains gradually give way to dry plains. Small settlements appear briefly along the road, highlighting the vast scale of Mongolia—where nature always leads the way. Dinner and overnight in a hotel.
AltaiExpedition.day14text: Visit the mysterious Shatar Chuluu, ancient stone formations standing silently on the steppe. Their purpose is still debated, adding to their intrigue. Camp nearby under open skies for a quiet night surrounded by history and endless grassland. Dinner and overnight in a tent.
AltaiExpedition.day15text: Return to Kharkhorin, the historic heart of Mongolia. Spend the day reflecting on your journey, revisiting familiar sites, or simply resting. The past feels close here, offering a calm and thoughtful pause before returning to the modern world. Dinner and overnight in a guest house with shower facilities.
AltaiExpedition.day16text: Drive back to Ulaanbaatar, where your journey comes full circle. The bustling streets feel different after weeks in nature. Bid farewell to Mongolia with memories of mountains, deserts, nomads, and a land that leaves a deep impression. Enjoy a farewell dinner together. Overnight in a hotel.

Terms.title: Terms & Conditions
Terms.contract_text: When you book a tour or other travel arrangements our contract with you takes effect when we send you a written Booking Confirmation / Invoice by email. Once the contract is made we are responsible for providing you with the tour you have booked and you are responsible to pay us for it, in each case subject to terms and conditions.
Terms.note_text: It is important to check carefully the Booking Confirmation and the Itinerary of your tour when you receive it that all the details are exactly as you requested. Our responsibility is to provide you with the services you have booked as described in the itinerary and as confirmed to you. If your group consists of two or more people traveling together, the person who makes the tour booking by signing our booking form or otherwise contracting with us accepts the responsibility for making all payments to us for all members of the party. We will send all the documents and other relevant information to the lead guest, and the lead guest is responsible for ensuring that the other members of the party are kept fully informed. If you are aged under 18 /on the departure date/ and your parents or guardians are not traveling with you, we must have their written consent to proceed with the booking.
